review.title: Planning over Chain Causal Graphs for Variables with Domains of Size 5 Is NP-Hard
review.abstract: Recently, considerable focus has been given to the problem of determining the boundary between tractable and intractable planning problems. In this paper, we study the complexity of planning in the class C_n of planning problems, characterized by unary operators and directed path causal graphs. Although this is one of the simplest forms of causal graphs a planning problem can have, we show that planning is intractable for C_n (unless P = NP), even if the domains of state variables have bounded size. In particular, we show that plan existence for C_n^k is NP-hard for k>=5 by reduction from CNFSAT. Here, k denotes the upper bound on the size of the state variable domains. Our result reduces the complexity gap for the class C_n^k to cases k=3 and k=4 only, since C_n^2 is known to be tractable.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: There is an ongoing effort in the planning community to determine the complexity of the various classes of planning problems, a problem that simplifies the process. Known tractable classes are usually characterized by a simple causal graph structure accompanied by additional constraints on variables and operators. However, the boundary between tractable and intractable planning problems is not yet clearly defined; the present paper contributes a novel complexity problem for a class of planning problems with simple causal graphics from the literature, in an effort to reduce these complexity problems, but is not of purely theoretical interest. For example, complex planning problems can be projected onto tractable fragments of planning problems to be used during the search (Katz & Domshlak, 2008b). Also, the causal variable heuristic (Helmert, 2006) uses the hierarchical structure of a planning problem by transforming it into a multiform.

sections.heading: 2. Related Work
sections.text: The complexity of planning problems has been extensively studied over the past twenty years (Bylander, 1994; Chapman, 1987; Erol, Nau, & Subrahmanian, 1995), and many detectable classes of planning problems exploit the notion of a causal graph in one way or another. Knoblock (1994) is usually credited with introducing the causal graph into his work on hierarchical planning. Williams and Nayak (1997) required planning problems to have an acyclic causal graph in an effort to ensure traceability. Jonsson and Ba � ckstro � m (1998) defined class 3S of planning problems, also with acyclic causal graphs, and showed that the plan existence is verifiable for that class. Domshlak and Dinitz (2001) introduced class Cn of the planning problems examined in this paper, as well as several related classes that all show a specific graphical structure.

sections.text: In this paper, we have shown that the problem of determining whether a plan for solving planning problems exists in class Ckn = > It is NP-hard whenever k ≥ 5. In contrast, Brafman and Domshlak (2003) is a multi-level time algorithm for generating plans that solve planning problems in class C2n. What can be said about the incidents, namely Ck n for k ² 3, 4}? Below, we outline some arguments for and against the tractability of these cases. Although the discussion is largely based on intuition gained by studying these classes, it could prove helpful for someone trying to determine their complexity. On the one hand, it seems likely that the plan existence for C4n is also hard. Our reduction for C5n uses only one type of state variable whose domain is greater than 4, namely v2ij.
